title: Quantification and reproducibility assessment of the regional brain T 2 relaxation in naïve rats at 7T
abstract: To measure the reproducibility of T2 relaxation and to determine the statistical power of T2 mapping in the rat brain as a characteristic of the baseline performance of the T2 relaxation as a potential biomarker of neurotoxicity.Multislice multiecho spin-echo imaging was utilized to obtain the quantitative T2 maps in 138 naïve rats at 7T. Images were skull-stripped and coregistered to the common anatomical reference. A full anatomical segmentation mask, which included all major brain structures, was created using the same reference T2 map. The overall variability map was also calculated from all T2 maps and the areas with arbitrarily high variability (coefficient of variation >25%) were excluded from the full segmentation mask to produce a trimmed mask. T2 maps were segmented using both these masks and statistical power analysis was conducted in all segmented areas.The coefficient of variation of T2 relaxation in different brain areas varied from 5.4% (cerebrospinal fluid) to 1.2% (cortex) when using a full segmentation mask. The use of a trimmed segmentation mask decreased the coefficient of variation in many areas, which ranged between 3.2% (inferior colliculi) and 1.2% (cortex) in this case. As revealed by statistical power analysis to detect 5% change with power of 0.8, the minimum number of observations needed for different areas ranged from 3 (cortex) to 8 (inferior colliculi) in the case of use of a trimmed segmentation mask.T2 relaxation is a very reproducible MRI parameter of the rat brain with high statistical power, which allows detecting very small changes in groups consisting of a minimal number of experimental animals.1 J. Magn. Reson. Imaging 2017;45:700-709.

motivations: There is a need to assess the reproducibility of T2 relaxation as a potential biomarker of neurotoxicity in the rat brain.
Understanding the statistical power of T2 mapping is crucial for determining its effectiveness in detecting small changes in the brain.
objectives: Measure the reproducibility of T2 relaxation in naïve rats at 7T.
Determine the statistical power of T2 mapping in detecting small changes in the rat brain.
methods: Utilize multislice multiecho spin-echo imaging to obtain quantitative T2 maps in naïve rats.
Apply anatomical segmentation masks to analyze T2 relaxation in different brain areas.
Conduct statistical power analysis to determine the minimum number of observations needed to detect small changes.
results: T2 relaxation is a highly reproducible MRI parameter in the rat brain with low variability.
The use of a trimmed segmentation mask can decrease variability and increase statistical power in detecting small changes.
Minimal numbers of experimental animals are required to detect small changes in T2 relaxation using the trimmed segmentation mask.

motivations: There is a need to establish baseline performance characteristics of T2 relaxation as a potential biomarker for neurotoxicity in the brain.
Understanding the reproducibility and statistical power of T2 mapping is essential for its reliable application in neuroimaging studies.
objectives: Measure the reproducibility of T2 relaxation in different regions of the rat brain at 7T.
Determine the statistical power of T2 mapping and establish the minimum sample sizes needed to detect meaningful changes in brain tissue.
methods: Multislice multiecho spin-echo imaging was used to obtain quantitative T2 maps from naïve rats at 7T.
Images were skull-stripped, coregistered to a common anatomical reference, and segmented using both full and trimmed anatomical masks.
Statistical power analysis was conducted to determine the minimum number of observations needed to detect changes in different brain regions.
results: T2 relaxation showed high reproducibility with coefficient of variation ranging from 1.2% to 5.4% across different brain regions.
Statistical power analysis revealed that detecting a 5% change requires only 3-8 observations depending on the brain region.
T2 relaxation demonstrated high statistical power as a reproducible MRI parameter capable of detecting small changes with minimal experimental animals.
